content:
As others said, the fact that first three tests lead you to some solution and then the fourth test fails is very annoying. We're here to learn, practice, have fun. Intentionally misleading reverse clashes serve none of these purposes.

<rant>And those two approvers (one with comment "Nice", second with empty comment) deserve being stripped of their approve rights.</rant>

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Tests cases do not match validators
Some solutions can match most of the tests cases and yet fail every validators.

My first solution : 

print(*(a[1] for a in sorted(zip(second, first))))

matches the 3 first tests cases but not the 4th. And no validator at all.

And It correspond to the goal.

This mean:
- That the tests cases are not relevant enough.
- That the validators do not tests the same thing as the test cases.

An easy test case to help the coder could be :
2 3 1 4 5 7 6
2 3 1 4 5 7 6
output : 3 1 2 4 5 6 7

And another:
9 9 9 8 8 7
2 4 1 6 3 5
output : 9 8 9 7 9 8

Validators do not correspond to their tests cases.
In particular all tests cases includes all numbers for 1 to N with N the number of numbers.
You could have a code passing all test cases and yet failing the validators.

The validators should be similar to their test case. Just different to avoid hardcoded answers.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Took me a bit of time to understand, but pretty cool when you understand it!

In your stub, don't use the same variable name.
Maybe you could write :

read first:string(1024)
read second:string(1024)
write your answer

Otherwise, it's a nice contribution.
Here is my JS solution :

r=x=>readline().split` `
a=r()
print(r().map(x=>a[+x-1]).join` `)

The test cases include numbers in range to make it more logical and reverse-mode friendly.
The validators aren't just to avoid hardcoded answers, but also to make sure you've provided a working solution to the problem. I designed it so it wouldn't be straightforward; even thought it's easy to understand that you have to map an array, it's not that easy to understand how.

It's because you didn't understand how it works. your solution is simply wrong, and the validators are here to verify it.

The first 3 cases give you an idea of what you need to do (aka mapping the first array according to the second array), yet the last test case is the interesting one, where you understand how to map it. it's designed for reverse mode.
You didn't understand at all how it works, so it's legit if you don't approuve it. Think again about the validators, and you'll see what is wrong with your solution.

I just underwent this Clash of code and ended up with a solution that pass 100% of the tests and 0% on the validators.

That should not happen and would not have if you had taken Flaaamort's comment into account. Moreover, an answer that claims to look at the validators to find the solution is irrelevant since they are not available during the clash.


After cleaning to make it more readable, here is the code I ended up with:

first = list(map(int,input().split()))
second = list(map(int,input().split()))
d1 = {i+1:k for i,k in enumerate(first)}
d2 = {i+1:k for i,k in enumerate(second)}
print(*[d1[d2[i+1]] for i in range(max(first))])

PS: You do not need to tell me how to fix it, I already found out.
